content.raw:
This might be what you're already saying, but I think the issue is that the `export` and `install` commands skip over putting the target file into the build directory. After all, the build system itself doesn’t need to dump the target information into a file since that information is readily available to it in memory.

I suspect the best way to handle this would be to try to do a real fake install instead of trying to spoof a fake install. That should also have the benefit of making this script maintainable. I’ll admit that I don’t know a way of doing that off the top of my head, but I have a feeling we’re not the first people to need that kind of functionality from cmake.
content.html:
This might be what you're already saying, but I think the issue is that the export and install commands skip over putting the target file into the build directory. After all, the build system itself doesn’t need to dump the target information into a file since that information is readily available to it in memory.

I suspect the best way to handle this would be to try to do a real fake install instead of trying to spoof a fake install. That should also have the benefit of making this script maintainable. I’ll admit that I don’t know a way of doing that off the top of my head, but I have a feeling we’re not the first people to need that kind of functionality from cmake.
